results.title: Going outside: to play, to imagine, to learn
results.creator_credit: Rick Cavaggion and Open College of Further Education (S. Aust.)
results.brief_description: Outlines ways in which teachers can develop children’s awareness of the natural environment. In a bush setting, five to eleven-year-olds role play the Dam Conflict Game, learning how to become involved in an issue and how to communicate their feelings.

results.title: Through a looking glass; Drama is -
results.creator_credit: Vincent O'Donnell and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Two drama education programs: “Through a looking glass” shows the major concepts underlaying drama in education and how the teacher can participate with the student in the dramatic process. “Drama is -” explores the ways in which drama can be used as a method to teach many subject areas.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vincent O’Donnell and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development

results.title: Suburban streetscape: living Hawthorn 1906 & 1979
results.creator_credit: Michael Rogers, Weston Bate and Deakin University
results.brief_description: Compares 1906 footage of the main streets of the Melbourne suburb of Hawthorn with footage of the same streets in 1979. Contains b&w footage.

results.title: Up against it
results.creator_credit: Cath Cantlon and Henley Beach Mural Collective
results.brief_description: A documentary on the painting of a large mural on a sea wall at Adelaide’s Henley Beach. Shows the design considerations, research, the process of involving the local council and school students, and the preparation and painting of the wall.

results.title: You've got to start somewhere
results.creator_credit: Chris Warner, Maureen McCarthy and Trout Films
results.brief_description: Focuses on a multicultural project at Ferntree Gully Primary School to show what teachers at schools with low migrant populations can do to put the philosophy of education in a multicultural society into practice.

results.title: Social security benefits: right or privilege?
results.creator_credit: Roger Ley, David Gardner and Centre for Study of Higher Education, University of Melbourne
results.brief_description: Outlines the work of a field officer with the Commonwealth Department of Social Security. Shows how the evidence found by the field officer can determine the continuation or cessation of a benefit. See also “Branda’s appeal”.

results.title: Leah; Water rats; Alison; Tracey
results.creator_credit: Sabina Baltrukomis and New South Wales. Dept. of Health
results.brief_description: A compilation tape consisting of four programmes designed to promote discussion in the area of human relations. 1. Leah. Concerns the feelings of an adolescent girl in regard to her alcoholic father who embarrasses her in front of her friends. 2. Water rats. Looks at the peer pressure exerted amongst a group of adolescents to conform to the group’s standards. 3. Alison. Looks at the problems of an adolescent girl who cannot adjust to her single father’s need to have adult female companionship. 4 Tracey. Considers the situation of an adolescent girl subjected to pressure by her domineering father to perform well academically.

results.title: The Volunteer Youth Program
results.creator_credit: Jack White, Andrew Scollo and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: Highlights the depressing effect that prolonged unemployment can have upon a young person’s self-confidence and that involvement in community work can provide an opportunity for people between jobs to exercise a sense of choice in their career. Explains the resources of the Volunteer Youth Program providing a sample of the range of activities - theatre, public radio and child care.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack White, Andrew Scollo and Open Channel Productions

results.title: Gia mas (About us)
results.creator_credit: Parthena Savvidou, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: After her mother left, Parthena Savvidou and her father fled to Greece to live with Parthena’s grandparents for six years before their eventual return to Australia. This story is about Parthena’s memories of life in Greece and her special relationship with her father. A thank you from a daughter to her father.
